newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy's Versace slashes prices to prepare for float.
newsitem.headline: Italy's Versace slashes prices to prepare for float.

text.p: One of Italy's top fashion design houses, Gianni Versace, will continue to slash prices across its full range of designer clothes and accessories in preparation for a flotation on the Milan stock market by June 1998.

Santo Versace, brother of world renowned designer Gianni and chairman of the group Gianni Versace, said on Tuesday the group will continue to cut prices in its autumn/winter 1997/98 season giving average price cuts of 15-20 percent in the last two years.
He hopes that the price cut move will boost volume sales and increase productivity and hence profit margins will be maintained. He stresses there will be no reduction in quality.
Gianni Versace is due to show its autumn/winter 1997/98 collection at the Milan fashion show later this week.
"We have cut our prices for the last three seasons and after the next season the average cut in prices will be 15-20 percent," said Versace in an interview with Il Sole 24 Ore.

He added that a planned flotation for the end of 1997 had to be delayed as the group wanted to complete its restructuring. He now sees a Milan listing by June 1998, and adds that the group is interested in a listing on Wall Street.
The Milan-based fashion house saw 1996 sales up 23.5 percent at 845 billion lire ($500 million), which of 80 percent is sold abroad, and Versace sees a further 20 percent rise in sales in 1997.
Some 56 percent of sales were in clothing, with accessories accounting for 25 percent, perfumes 15 percent, and household furnishing items some four percent.
Group pretax profits for the year 1996 rose 13.6 percent to 175 billion lire. ($1=1,704)
